reviewText:
Future Legend picks up beautifully where the original Bit Trip Runner leaves off. It has you playing as CommanderVideo, jumping, blocking and springjumping his way across 5 different worlds to escape back to his crew.

The game expands wonderfully on the original, with different playable characters, costumes, challenges, bonuses, dance combos, the lot. It looks better, it controls better and it feels better.

Nor does the game ramp up towards the end arbitrarily, but instead puts difficulty into the game thematically.

Really super fun, completed each level on hardest difficulty within 7 hours. Check this game out!

Nilesy
voteText: 83 of 91 people (91%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
If you weren't the biggest fan of the original RUNNER's harsh difficulty swings, lack of checkpointing, and sometimes confusing visuals but actually thought the concept was pretty neat and fun, then I'd highly suggest giving RUNNER2 a go.  Everything about RUNNER2's gameplay feels as if it was developed in direct response to criticisms of the first game and is definitely more approachable and polished than before.  If you just straight up didn't like the original game however, this one isn't going to change your mind.

The setup is largely the same with the only chief differences being the spiffy and colorful new aesthetic and changes that make the game a bit easier to handle. If you were a fan of the original's retro visual style, you'll likely be disappointed with the more distinct cartoony look and sound of RUNNER2, but if you were a fan of the gameplay, you're still in for a treat.

The biggest and most requested change is that there are now optional mid-stage checkpoints, which can make learning stages a bit easier. It's up to you whether you want a score bonus or a safety net, so there's a nice little element of risk vs reward here. The difficulty curve is straight up perfect this time around, with really nice ramp ups in challenge where they need to be with some easier stages sprinkled throughout to keep the bloodpressure down. Stages feel more like complete songs now, each with a really nice build up and repetition of patterns and mechanics with really nice flourishes at the end.

RUNNER2 is also a much bigger game than the original, containing 125 stages (100 normal stages and 25 hidden retro warp zones), multiple characters to play as, tons of unlockable costumes, and some Super Mario World'ey alternate exits toat can open up different paths in each world. I certainly found a lot of enjoymen in wanting to unlock everything, but you don't really need that mentality to enjoy what the game has to offer.

Overall, RUNNER2 is simply a better game in every respect. The new visual designs may turn off some fans, but they don't affect the core gameplay which is still solid as hell.

reviewText:
Like a million times better than Runner 1.

Looks gorgeous. I know Runner 1 had that 2D retro thing it was rocking but this honestly looks so much better. And it still has 2D retro stages so those sort of make up for it. Oh, and more importantly you can access them from the map screen this time so no having to replay the level perfectly on one life ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t anymore too.

Actual replayability this time. Branching paths. Unlockable (strange) characters. 3 difficulty levels.

CHECKPOINTS. IF YOU HAVEN'T PLAYED THE FIRST THEN YOU WON'T UNDERSTAND HOW GLORIOUS OF AN IMPROVEMENT THEIR INCLUSION IS. IF YOU TRIED THE FIRST ONE AND HATED IT YOU PROBABLY QUIT ON ODYSSEY. I KNOW. Hell, the option to skip them for extra points is great too.

Still frustrating as hell because your eyes tend to blur things after a certain point and there's still somewhat of an element of trial and error memorization or clutch reflex things you need to pull off. But this time it isn't enough to turn me off from this game.

I probably missed stuff but yeah, worth a pick up. Runner 1 is okay but there is a clear drop-off point at the end of the first world because they took everything that ruined the game and shoved it all into the longest level in the game.

reviewText:
Graphics/Design - 8
Sound - 9
Gameplay - 10
Value - 6

This game really came out of nowhere for me.  Having never played any of the Bit Trip games, I'd read rave reviews about this game and about how good it was.  The first thing you notice when you start the game are the vibrant colors and beautiful backgrounds.  The art style is really clean and crisp; it makes everything easy to see and prepare for.  This is important because every jump, slide, bounce, block, super bounce and slide jump you do are all in rhythm to the song playing in each level.  Bad controls would absolutely break this game because of how time sensitive it is so I'm happy to say they are nearly flawless.  A players success with this game is going to be solely based on how good their hand-eye coordination is.  With sound being so important it's a good thing then, that the music is generally upbeat and enjoyable.  It gives a relaxing feel that works well even though the game itself is about timing and reaction.

If you pick up every item in a level and beat it you get a Perfect" rating.  You can also get a "Perfect+" which is picking up every item along with getting shot out of a canon that moves up and down and hitting a red bullseye at the end of a level.  This can be really frustrating if you're trying to get Perfect+ on every level
date: say for an achievement that requires it.  You might be playing on hard and on the 10th try you finally beat the level
recommended: pick up every item and now it's time to try and hit the bullseye.  There's no surefire way to hit it other than sort of feeling it's the right moment to fire.  If you miss and you want the Perfect+ you'll have to play the whole level over again to get the chance to hit the bullseye again.  This is literally the only thing in the game that might detract from someones enjoyment of it in any way.\n\nIt's not a huge game taking around 5 hours to get through the first time but Hard mode is where the game really shines as it fills in a lot more of the song with obstacles and enemies that are missing on easier difficulties.  You can also play 8-bit retro levels that are hidding throughout stages.  I didn't find them anywhere near as enjoyable as the main game however.  Bottom line
hoursPlayed:
this is a great game that should be enjoyed by everywhere and a game that can brighten your day whenever you play it.

Single Player Play Time - 5-6 hours

Overall 8.5"

reviewText:
By far the best entry in the Bit.Trip series, and completely worth it even if you hated the first Bit.Trip Runner or any other games in the series.

Runner 2 isn't even comparable to any of the other Bit.Trip games due to it's depature from a retro style and is more akin to the likes of Trials Evolution due to the outstanding visuals, insane amount of content and unlockables, and an overall amazing quality of level design with multiple paths and lots of decision making thrown in.

Runner2: Future Legend of Rhythm Alien is easily the most fun you'll have with a Bit.Trip game and has by far the most forgiving learning curve in the series, this belongs in every platform gaming fans' library!

reviewText: BIT.TRIP Presents... Runner2: Future Legend of Rhythm Alien is the direct sequel of BIT.TRIP Runner. It has a lot in common with its predecessor, but it features different graphics. In addition to almost a hundred levels set across five different worlds, it also features retro levels which are reminiscent of the 8-bit era. Unfortunately, it only features singleplayer gameplay. In general, BIT.TRIP Presents... Runner2: Future Legend of Rhythm Alien is a great platformer for everybody and it stands as a welcome addition to the BIT.TRIP series.

reviewText: No doubt the best rhythm platformer there is. Once the beat kicks in and you're on a roll on hard mode there is something magical about the music it creates. Graphics look brilliant unlike the first game, further proving that indie developers need to stop it with the lazy retro art styles. Characters can now dance meaning you can risk doing so in stages for points adding a great competitive element if you are into leaderboards but there is more than enough challenge and replayability to be found anyway.

reviewText:
I beat every level on the hardest difficulty but i wouldn't recommend the game for several reasons.

The controls are not rebindable:
The keyboard controls are an abomination - almost unplayable and they don't even offer alternative keybindings or anything. Same problem with a gamepad (i played most of it with an xbox controller), so it turns out that jump and kick is X and A and because they are so close together some random level in world 3 or 4 is the hardest in the whole game because you have to do a couple of successive jumpkicks up some stairs.
For someone playing quite a few precision platformers this is mind-boggling, how could anyone think that buttons that you need to alternate quickly should be so close together, the most annoying part is that kicking before jumping sometimes cancels out the kick. Even worse is that the shoulder buttons are not used for anything but dancing, if the shoulder buttons would be kick and block gamepad controls would be fine.

Checkpoints = Chokepoints
Before hitting a checkpoint you get slowed down, in later levels there are a few checkpoints that are positioned so poorly that the slowdown will simply kill you, even if you memorize the spot it is very irritating and completly ruins your timing every single time.

White on White:
So the first 2 worlds have white/greyish backgrounds and grey enemies, making them hard to see. Enemies in general look all rather similiar, because of that you sometimes die because you couldn't properly see the enemy instead of actually hard gameplay sequences.

Cannon-Minigame:
Most levels are easier than bit.trip runner 1 even on the hardest difficulty, but not getting a perfect+ because being slightly off with the cannon is just a way to artificially increase the playtime, even if you get good at the cannon minigame you will miss a couple times.

Beating the game perfect+ hardest difficulty on every level isn't good enough:
No, to 100% the game you have to play every level on all 3 difficultys and get the cannon-minigame perfect on every single level. Compared to bit.trip runnner 1 the levels on the hardest difficulty are rather easy, but playing on easy is so boring that i can't believe some people actually completed the game with 100%.

Dancing mechanic:
I don't even know how this mechanic could make it in the game. So if you want to get highscores you have to dance pretty much every second you can, artificially increasing the difficulty for yourself because the game isn't designed tighter.

I think that covered the most big problems i had with the game, despite all that i played through the game, compared to bit.trip runner 1 it is way more casual but offers fun for a couple hours.

reviewText:
I'm not quite sure what I expected before I played Runner2, probably another obstacle course with the same clear-cut pixel graphics and simple charm of the prequel Runner, perhaps with a bit more underlying menace or excitement pursuant to a Rhythm Alien which apparently featured in it. What I got was something with the same basic gameplay, but with a lot of extras.
Extras? Extras are good, right? If you played the first Runner, there was almost nothing more satifying than getting an extra, then speeding along with the music at full audibility, collecting gold with a rainbow contrail stretching to infinity. Sadly though, in this version, extras result in a watery rainbow which trails sadly in your wake, and the music doesn't really noticably change throughout the course of a level. I suppose that anything less wouldn't fit the new 'style' of the game.
No, these extras are the normal sort of game extras, extra characters and collectable outfits and a 'reward' system. Collectible outfits? If you're still thinking of the first BIT.TRIP Runner, you may be wondering how that works. I could tell you the first outfit was a pair of earbuds, and you might wonder if that meant whitining a couple pixels on the Runner's ears. Not to fear though, it's all part of the new 'style'.
At the beginning of the game, a smarmy narrator informs you that CommanderVideo has been sucked into an alternate dimension, while fighting in some manner of justice league. A new world awaits, with a lot more living things, and more importantly, real 3D graphics.
I don't feel that 3D graphics really do much for the game. I felt that my runner was not a s responsive due to the slower nature of the jump animation. In fact, starting out, the overhangs on staircases would always make me trip, as I was used to a more 2D perspective from playing the first runner. Moreover, when I tripped, the runner would swim backwards like an octopus, at a constant rate no matter where I was in the level, which was really irratating if I tripped towards the end (compare Runner, where returning to the start took a fixed amount of time, no matter what).
The presence of a lot more living things is worse for the feel of the game, though. In the first runner, the living things include huge tunneling worms, fish, clouds with mustaches, and trampolines with eyes. What all of these have in common though is that they are separated from your gameplay. None of them are beneficiaries or detractors to your Herculean run. Your enemies, such as they are, are robots. In Runner2, the first thing you see is a spike-thing sitting in the road. Then, as you go further on, a drunken pickle registers you at a checkpoint. This makes the aesthetic lonliness which the first game had impossible to acheive. End the level, and a sign flips to tell you it's an Amazing Acheivement!". If you've collected all the gold
date: you no longer get to go to a fiendishly difficult bonus level
recommended: but instead get fired out of a cannon.\nAs the game mechanics were introduced I noticed another thing I didn't like about this sequel

reviewText:
What a great game!

I just finished it, getting 'Triple Perfect+' on every level. This game is not for everyone. but I loved the difficulty and I would recommend it whole heartedly.

My biggest problem is that upon perfecting every level, there is cannon challenge. The cannon must be fired at a very precise moment in order to hit the bullseye of a target. This is the difference between a 'Perfect' and a 'Perfect+'
This is very annoying when you've just completed a level perfectly, skipped the checkpoint (grants 50,000 extra points) and made it to the end; because if you miss the bullseye, you must start the whole level over again.

Other gripes include the multiple intro screens before the main menu (I don't need a recap of what happened in the previous game every time I load up) and one level where you must to jump up some stairs while kicking, which wouldn't be a problem if the buttons where mapped differently, but there isn't any option to configure the controls.

Regardless of minor issues, this is still a fantastic game.

reviewText: Runner2 is an incredibly addictive music-based autorunner. Every successful action in the game is accompanied by an assortment of musical sounds, so you feel that (when you do well) you're a part of the soundtrack. This is such a great way to provide the player with positive feedback that really hooks into your brain. It's lovely. The player input is simple, based solely on the 4-way dpad, but as the levels become more complicated and start scrolling faster, requiring ever increasing tandem combinations of these inputs, the game becomes quite hectic. That said, the difficulty curve is consistently gentle and the most difficult sections are often entirely optional - mainly being alternate paths leading to bonus exits in each level. Simply put, this game is just a ton of fun. It's so colourful and once it clicks in your brain, you're left with a zen-like connection between music and puzzles that is impossible to stop playing.

reviewText:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dlzWXZ25CSI
Runner2 Future Legend of Rhythm Alien
Your task: run forward, collect gold and powerups, but dodge the various obstacles of living and nonliving genesis.
Unlike its predecessor BIT.TRIP RUNNER, Runner2 Future Legend of Rhythm Alien made with good graphics, without a touch of retro bit styling. This means that the probability of vertigo and epilepsy reduced to minimum.
Compared with BIT.TRIP RUNNER, gameplay became softer - to the levels added checkpoints. Checkpoints are located approximately at half of the distance.
Highly recommend to use a gamepad for playing, as well as stock up soothing. :)
For support gamepad you need to purchase additional software, example Pinnacle Game Profiler or Xpadder.

Runner2 Future Legend of Rhythm Alien
Ваша задача: бежать вперед, собирать золото и поверапы, да уворачиваться от различных препятствий живого и неживого генеза.
В отличие от своего предшественника BIT.TRIP RUNNER, Runner2 Future Legend of Rhythm Alien выполнен с хорошей графикой, без налета ретро квадратизма. А значит, вероятность головокружения и приступов эпилепсии сведена к минимому.
По сравнению с BIT.TRIP RUNNER, геймплей стал более мягким - на уровни добавлены чекпоинты, с которых игра возобновлятеся после натыкания на препятствие. Чекпоинты расположены примерно на половине дистанции.
Очень рекомендую использовать геймпад для прохождения, а также запастить успокоительным. :)
Для поддержки геймпада потребуется приобрести дополнительный софт, например Pinnacle Game Profiler или Xpadder.

reviewText:
BIT.TRIP Runner 2 (forgive me, but I'm not using the full name of the game) is a really fun... platformer? It's not really a platformer, more like a crash course of obstacles to avoid. Which might sound boring, but it's actually pretty fun!

The gameplay is relaxing, yet challenging; there hasn't been anything that made me ragequit, just try harder; the normal difficulty setting seems to be really balanced, and also implementing checkpoints makes the frustration factor go waaaay down. One note though, if you don't have a controller, you might have a bad time.

There is a lot to do here. 100 levels, with collectibles, chests, keys and other stuff. You can go for all the items, try the high score or try the deceptively tough warp zones (3 lives...) If you're a stickler for collecting, prepare to get sucked in.

Visuals are top-notch, the art style is really pleasing and in a sense idyllic. And of course, the most important factor in such a game, is the sound; I cannot praise the sound enough. The combination of your inputs and the visuals and the music, wonderfully composed of variously pitched sounds, make this game feel really complete and suck you in.

All of this makes this one of the one more level" genre games. And sure
recommended: as there is an end to all the challenges
hoursPlayed: but I'll be damned if you don't have lots of fun on the way there.\n\nStrongly recommend. Pick this up now

reviewText:
After 26 hours of playtime, unlocking everything, collecting everything, and getting every achievement I think I'm finally ready to review Bit.Trip Runner 2: Future Legend of Rhythm Alien.

When I played this game for the first time, it evoked the same feelings I experienced playing games like Super Mario World, Crash Bandicoot, and Tetris for the first time. You sit there, not realizing that you're smiling and moving to the music and even humming along, and then it hits you; you're a kid again, and there's not a care in the world. It's almost magical. It's also everything a sequel could hope to be in every category, and it's become one of my favorite games on Steam. I could go on and on with statements like these (and they would all be true) but all you really need to know is if the game is fun or not, and the answer to that is absolutely, joyously, colorfully YES.

This game is not only a loveletter to fans of the original game (on which it improves on everything fans asked and hoped for and then some) but also to anyone who is a fan of stylish, musically driven platformers or rhythm games. The world is vibrant, hilarious and creative with giant, cartoonish backgrounds that will sometimes even distract you from the game with how funny and imaginative the situations are. This goes without saying but the music, a major boon and pivotal component of the gameplay, is completely stellar. Each world has a new song and you'll want to collect all of the music pickups as soon as you can to add more and more layers to the beat. The levels are laid out in such a way that each jump, kick, bounce and deflection adds a complementary tune to the soundtrack, and it makes you feel like the songs are not just background audio but a real part of the experience. The gameplay has been reworked and is far more about actual skill, timing and reflexes than the original Bit.Trip Runner's reliance on memorization and punishment through repetition. The moves are simple; you can duck, kick, jump, and block. Simple, right? It's the way Gaijin Games combines these basic manuevers in the levels that give you a real challenge that never feels cheap or frustrating so that when you lose, you know why and you're raring for another shot. You know how to duck and you know how to jump, but what happens when you're faced with a grounded and floating pair of enemies with space in between? You duck and jump at the same time, of course! A floating enemy with a wall underneath? You kick while sliding! In this way every new challenge feels organic and satisfying because you are mixing these moves that you've mastered to navigate these mazes of music that the developers have created for you. Soon you're flying through the air, blocking cubes, shattering floating enemies, jumping and sliding at a pace that will make onlookers think you must have been playing this game for years.

There's 5 worlds complete with bonus stages and hidden retro courses, unlockable characters and costumes, three difficulties (and optional checkpoints, THANK GOD), leaderboards, challenges and achievements, so you'll be playing this game for quite a while if you want to see everything it has to offer. At the price this game goes for now on sale, it's really a no brainer. Pick it up, pick up the soundtrack, maybe even grab a copy for your friend. Yes, it's that good. Happy running!

reviewText: One of the best games I have on my Steam library as of now. Runner 2 takes the elements of the first Runner and makes it ten times more awesome. The music is amazing, espeically on Ultra. I like to play at maximum volume with earphones. And who cares of this music isn't fitting for the boss battles? Also, over 100 levels. That's a LOT of levels for a game like this! The game is also easy to beat. I finished it whole in one night. I was on Quite Easy though. But the main thrill comes from Rather Hard and I really enjoy it. Also, I especially love the theme and style of the game. With all kinds of cute dialogue, cutscenes and stuff. One other great thing, I find this game to be a REALLY good trainer for the first Runner, which is shorter but harder than this game. After playing this game for a while I went back to the first Runner and got a perfect (Not double) in every world.\n\nI recommend this game if you're into rhythm games, funny events, epic soundtracks, and easy indie gaming.

reviewText:
Runner2 manages to fit in a lot of character, challenge, and humor, in an unlikely place.

Bit.Trip Runner was simply too hard for me. My sense of rhythm and eyesight are both pretty terrible, so it was too much for me. Runner2 improves upon the original in every way, though the art style might be harder for some to read.

Revolving around a constant runner of your choice, you have to enter a series of combinations that both make music and allow your runner to progress to the end of the level. It may sound simple enough, but the difficulty ramps up on its own, and the level of challenge can be controlled by the player. The levels rarely feel too long, and the check point can be a life saver.

Runner2 constantly gives incentives to keep you going, with humorous costumes and characters to unlock, leaderboards, retro levels, and great animation. The reverse merman and disco hamburger had me grinning even when I was stuck on the same section for an extended period.

Runner 2 is aesthetically pleasing with simple mechanics, great challenge, and lots of personality.

****The DLC is a great character pack. The characters offered in the pack are beloved and sure to please many gamers. Just like the characters unlocked in the base game, these characters are just cosmetically different, with great animation and style.

reviewText: The sequel to the classic Bit.Trip Runner game. Commander Video continues his journey in his neverending running along with new characters and an entertaining narrative by Mario himself, Charles Martinet. The game is similar like the last game with gameplay, but this time in 3D/2.5D graphics. There are alternate routes that lead to unlocking characters and chests that unlock costumes, even if they require a key. I surprisingly found this game to be more easier than the first game, but it has its fair share of difficulty. So overall, the sequel is a very excellent and well made game, and I highly reccomend it.

reviewText:
+ Absolutely fantastic soundtrack, the gameplay goes along with it very well.
+ Charming graphics style.
+ Much more forgiving (and therefore less frustrating) than BIT.TRIP RUNNER. The game offers you three difficulty settings (so there's something for everyone) and each level has a checkpoint (which you can skip for bonus points).
+ A good number of levels and collectibles.
+ Unlike RUNNER, this game has a proper score system which allows for highscore hunting.
+ Lots of customization.

- Acquiring a Perfect+ on a level requires you to hit the bullseye on the Bonus Chance minigame. Which is pretty pointless. Why not earn it by skipping the checkpoint instead?
- A tad too easy, even on Rather Hard.
- Stupid humor to be found throughout the game (such as the level names Tripping on Herbs" and "Sweaty Dangle". There's more.)

BIT.TRIP Presents... Runner2: Future Legend of Rhythm Alien is a great spinoff of the BIT.TRIP games and might even be the best auto-runner game yet. It's actually one of those rare games I decided to get 100% completion on.

8/10"

reviewText: I'm not sure what genre this game is, but it's a platformer where you can't stop running to the right. The enemies, obstacles, and items throughout the stages all make music when defeating, dodgeing, or collecting them. It sounds pretty neat when you go through a stage having everything make sounds. The game is also pretty challenging, but there is a checkpoint around halfway through a stage that you can retry from if you fail a stage. This is probably the best game of this type of genre that I have played. There are tons of collectables, rewards, and things to unlock. The game itself will take around 6 hours to finish, but you can easily add at least 6 more hours if you go for all the unlockables. Great game that I had a lot of fun with.

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ze-Q_Yr2ODY&list=PL0E56219EE956754E

BIT.TRIP Runner2: Future Legend of Rhythm Alien: A huge improvement over the previous installment. Another great example of what a sequel should be, BIT.TRIP Runner2: Future legend of Rhythm Alien does a great job of maintaining the expectation of the first game while improving and adding more to the series to make an even better game than the first. Not only is there more content, but the game overall has had a massive overhaul. The music is still just as great and is even more prominent in each level and it instantly becomes a joy to start running regardless of level and the sound design in general is greatly improved and it’s even narrated by Charles Martinet! The style and graphics have taken a huge turn for the better; the world is filled with even weirder worlds, colors, style than the previous game and, overall the game now resembles something more like a modern cartoon. The gameplay is still simple and more or less the same from the first, however levels have been improved, aside from the checkpoints now at about the mid-point of each level (which you can skip for bonus points) most levels have extra or various routes to take, some more difficult with greater rewards vs. easier routes or ones that will give you access to other levels. You can now also play different characters and unlock a great variety of costumes for each one. The game also has added more abilities you unlock to give greater variations to the scores you can earn in each level and it also has effortlessly combined leaderboards and scores from Steam friends right into the game and each level has different variations depending on the difficulty set; all this combined makes it a joy to play through each level and go back through ones you’ve beat to try to achieve a greater score or top friends who have also played.

BIT.TRIP Runner2: Future Legend of Rhythm Alien is a great sequel and if you’ve already played the first game the sequel should be a no brainer purchase. For those of you interested in the first game, I recommend picking up Runner2 as it offers a lot more and it is only $15.00 USD, only $5 more than the first game. BIT.TRIP Runner2 is a great game, it’s challenging, easy to play, difficult to perfect and master and it has loads of unlockable stuff and, can easily entertain you with its fast action and great music. Definitely pick this up if you enjoy arcade styled games, fast paced games, games that capitalize on music or family friendly games, it truly is a game everyone can enjoy and for the asking price you really can’t get much better than this.

-Double Thumbs Up from Royial

Video Reviews can be found at: www.youtube.com/user/RoyialNetwork

reviewText:
BIT.TRIP Runner2 is more of the same rhythm/platforming like that of its prequel, BIT.TRIP RUNNER.
No longer are the graphics and sound reminiscent of the 8-bit retro style (with exception of the Retro bonus levels), but fear not, this isn't necessarily a bad thing. The game looks and sounds much better, and Runner2's gameplay seems more forgiving than its predecessor. Levels now have checkpoints, which could be entirely avoided if one so desires. The bonus retro levels, once found, can be completed without having to go thru the main level again. And the difficulty isn't quiet as intense as in RUNNER although it still offers 3 difficulty settings. One of which being Rather Hard" which could still be challenging to any RUNNER veteran.

reviewText: Some things that the BIT.TRIP games have always done well are pacing and rhythm. With this installment, not only do these tropes continue, but with flair that the series has never attempted. This is the same old rhythm platformer you know, with more personality and accessibility; a refreshing step from the classic, and in my eyes, a damn good sequel. The new art style is a particularly welcome feature in my book. The visuals are very slick and aberrantly fitting. The music is encapturing, as one may expect from a BIT.TRIP game. The controls are responsive. Everything seems to mesh together well into a melting pot of skill, reflex, and sometimes, luck. This time around, the gameplay is expanded to make the experience more accessible. Hardcore rhythm challenge-seekers (or challenge-seekers in general) shouldn't worry; the difficulty is just as punishing as one would assume, it can simply be toned down. Casual players also are welcomed due to this, and that is why I would recommend the game to players of all types. It's for everyone.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: What a difference. While the previous Runner suffered from monotonously long levels and strict inputs, this game not only improves mechanically and graphically but expands enough to breathe. Multiple paths loaded with secrets are facilitated by the addition of midlevel checkpoints -- and don't worry, hardcore gamers, you can always skip the checkpoint for score if you're feeling daring. Scoring is part showmanship, part white-knuckled risk-reward... with just a pinch of playful absurdism right at the end. Like everything else in this game, it's tongue-in-cheek but surprisingly clever.

reviewText:
I really liked everthing about this game

It doesn't require long sessions at a time to progress (although you might find yourself playing long sessions), you can pick it up and play however long you want and unlock another level or improve at the game.

There are a few difficulty settings for every player but if your after 100% acheivements your going to want to play the harder setting eventually. It took me around 36 Hours to 100%. One of the levels had a large set of stairs that i ended up buying a new keyboard for. My basic keyboard wans't cutting it so i upgraded to a mechanical keyboard.

There is a checkpoint half way through each level (on the rare occasion two), unlike the first Bit.Trip Runner (which i found more difficult)

There is a choice of charecters that gradually get unlocked as you progress, as well as a few skins for them.

I found this game very addicting, all the things contributing to the music making the play even more fun and times of intensity where i was on the edge of my seat.

Loved it and Highly reccomend 10/10

reviewText:
An excellent sequel. It takes what was wrong with the first game and revamps it to make it more enjoyable.

Gameplay is simple to get a hold of, and the difficulty curve rises at a good rate. The three difficulty settings allow you to tailor your experience to how much of a challenge you're after, and the Just Right" difficulty provided enough of a challenge for me to enjoy the game from start to finish. There is a good amount of incentive to replaying levels with unlockable characters and costumes as well as collecting Retro cartridges.

The biggest difference from the first game to this one is the addition of Checkpoints - and the best part about these is that they are optional. For someone like me
date: who grew rapidly frustrated with the first game
recommended: the addition of Checkpoints is a welcome change. For those who enjoy the challenge
hoursPlayed: you can simply jump over them for extra points rather than using them.\nAnother change is the implementation of multiple pathways
voteText: which is a neat idea but I always went for the "dangerous" route regardless - and I did not feel the need to go back and do another path unless there was an alternate exit or a hidden treasure. Both pathways lead to the end and have the same amount of gold
helpfulPercent: so unless there's a treasure there's not much point to making the choice other than
votesHelpful: again
votesTotal: deciding how much of a challenge you want.\n\nVisuals are very aesthetically pleasing and the design for the menus
commentsCount: and world map are nice and consistent. Some of the character designs were a little -too- weird for my taste but for the most part they are fun and interesting. Sound is great; Charles Martinet does some great voiceover work and the music - as to be expected - is well-suited to the gameplay and easy on the ears.\n\nI highly recommend this game. It's a fun platformer with a neat twist that will easily fill some spare time."

reviewText:
So, this game has me in two spots - both of which say you need to play this game.

First off, this game is gorgeous, fun, and sounds glorious. The music is relaxing, yet nuanced enough to build tension. There have been plenty of times where I've played, and then realized that I'd been holding my breath for 45 seconds due to the mounting tension of the music coming to a crescendo.

On the other hand, it's one of the most logically designed games with a smart difficulty ramp up that, ♥♥♥♥, really gets hard as hell the farther you go. It's almost like the designers looked at what made old games great, put their own spin on it after dropping about 47 tabs of acid, and proceeded to vomit forth one of the most charming and enjoyable games I've ever played.

I mean, ♥♥♥♥, there's a character named Hamburger Whetfahrt in it. And a fish with gigantic, swinging, bulbous testicles. What more could you ask for?

reviewText:
BTR2 does an excellent job of improving over its predecessor by distilling down the fun parts of the original and rebuilding itself around those concepts. Functionally it serves as a kind of pure-reflex rhythm game, with musical themes which bear repeating and creative use of an xbox-style controller. The visual upgrade to faux three-dimensionality does not accompany floaty or imprecise controls as is so often the case – in fact, the sequel has even tighter controls than the first, and every obstacle is clearly delineated without interrupting the overall graphical style.

Playing BTR2 can be a soothing, cathartic experience, but with variable difficulty levels and lots of hidden secrets there are plenty of challenges floating beneath the surface. This game is perfect for gamers of any age and ability, so long as they can enjoy Katamari-style quirkiness and the sense of achievement that comes with well-honed reflexes.

reviewText:
Bit.Trip Runner 2 is the sequel to the original Bit.Trip Runner game, with lots of changes to bring another fantastic game. Since this game is a directly numbered sequel, there are some similarities between the two games. One thing to note is the series's trademark pixelized art style is changed to a more stylized and cartoony look. Overall, the worlds are less brightly colored and flashy but still are trippy or weird in nature. The music is also not chiptune in nature, but still has the style of Bit.Trip to it. Some songs wil be familiar to those who played prior games like Runner, and the music is still electronica based. Most fans of the original Bit.Trip games might bemoan these changes, but they actually are a refreshing change and still carry the same kind of charm and style that makes this a Bit.Trip game. The story continues from the ending of Runner, with all of Commander Video's friends and Mingrawn Timbletot being in the cutscenes. However, Commander Video is sent into an alternate dimension and chases after Mingrawn Timbletot in this more cartoony dimension.

The gameplay naturally takes after Bit.Trip Runner. Players keep running and must dodge obstacles using several abilities. Runner 2 adds new objects in the levels to mix things up, such as a loop the loop, speed boosts, and rails. Additionally, the player has a few more abilities to use to navigate new obstacles. Included in every level are checkpoints that players will restart at if they hit an obstacle after that checkpoint. The checkpoint may be skipped to earn bonus points, but at the expense of starting from the beginning of the level if they mess up. Alternate paths are showcased more in the game, and even have signs showing which paths are easier or harder. The harder paths tend to give more points, but may also have a treasure chest to unlock costumes or even unlock a new level with an alternate exit. Some levels also have keys which must be activated first from a Key Vault level. The levels with keys then are to be replayed to unlock a padlock and get another treasure chest. The difficulty tends to be easier than Runner on the Just Right difficulty thanks to the checkpoints making levels more bearable and the difficulty curve not being too extreme like in the first game. Runner 2's Hard mode should give a challenging set of levels with a difficulty not unlike the previous Runner game. There are more levels overall in Runner 2, which should make this game longer than the 5 hours of gameplay expected in the first Runner game.

Bit.Trip Runner 2 might look a bit different in style to other Bit.Trip games, but this game is just as fun as the first Runner game. Runner 2 boasts more features in the gameplay and is a longer experience while having the signature Bit.Trip style to the game. With a fun cartoony style and a variety of levels with good music, different level designs, and more fair difficulty, Runner 2 is sure to be a great experience that gives challenges and different things to be expecting.

reviewText:
Sublime level design, wonderful music, and addresses every single issue from Runner 1. Also has one of the most... unique... art styles and senses of humor that I've seen in a long time. It’s creepy in a surprisingly hilarious way, and it’s certainly something new.

Okay, I’ll give. This is a ten-out-of-ten game. My one complaint was the unreliable and slightly luck-based dancing mechanic for high scores, but I managed to get to Rank 9 on the global leaderboard without trying very hard, so I can’t complain too much. Besides, you can enjoy this game just fine without even caring about score.

This is the best fixed-speed runner game on the market right now, and future runner games will have tall challenge if they want to top it.

This review brought to you in part by Shorty's Milk Brine: It could be worse."
"

reviewText:
Much easier than the first Bit Trip Runner, but still a very fun game.

The new graphics and art style are a huge improvement and the music and sounds are still great. It also features really good and fitting voice acting this time.

The gameplay is largely the same. A couple of new moves have been added (like kicking while sliding), some levels have branching paths (with difficult paths offering more rewards like extra characters and costumes) and each level has a checkpoint in the middle that you can skip for bonus points.

My only very minor complaint is with the cannon minigame at the end of each level. It’s very easy to ruin a perfect run by missing the bullseye, forcing you to restart the level. Thankfully the game is so good that replaying a level isn’t a punishment.

reviewText:
A great rhythm-based game for the perfectionist. I played exclusively with an Xbox controller and can only say that the game is great. I'm going to briefly go over some of the basics of the game: music, gameplay, challenge, etc.

The music interacts with the stage and really gets you into it, everytime I flick this game on I just can't stop hopping along with CommanderVideo as I hum and laugh-- It is truly a wonderfully perfect game. Handling CommanderVideo and his crew is fun and easy. The game eases you into the game within the first world and you never feel overwhelmed. Easy is easy. Normal is normal. Hard is challenging. The difficulties have been adjusted perfectly. Graphics are enjoyable and I run a solid 60+ fps with a gtx 770. Prior to upgrade from my Raedon 7670 I never noticed any major hiccups either.

I really don't know what to say, the game is great for newcomers and veterans, its a challenging casual game with huge amounts of replayability.

reviewText:
Major improvements over the first of the series that come to mind after only minutes of playing are:

- an in-game leaderboard of your steam friend's best scores for each level
- difficulty settings (easy, normal, hard) to enable the player to choose how to complete the levels, challenging the best players but still giving less apt-platform gamers the ability to play the game in its entirety.
- the checkpoint mid-level is genius, along with the bonus for skipping it to again provide extra challenge for those interested
- graphics look good

reviewText:
An excellent sequel. It takes what was wrong with the first game and revamps it to make it more enjoyable.

Gameplay is simple to get a hold of, and the difficulty curve rises at a good rate. The three difficulty settings allow you to tailor your experience to how much of a challenge you're after, and the Just Right" difficulty provided enough of a challenge for me to enjoy the game from start to finish. There is a good amount of incentive to replaying levels with unlockable characters and costumes as well as collecting Retro cartridges.

The biggest difference from the first game to this one is the addition of Checkpoints - and the best part about these is that they are optional. For someone like me
date: who grew rapidly frustrated with the first game
recommended: the addition of Checkpoints is a welcome change. For those who enjoy the challenge
hoursPlayed: you can simply jump over them for extra points rather than using them.\nAnother change is the implementation of multiple pathways
voteText: which is a neat idea but I always went for the "dangerous" route regardless - and I did not feel the need to go back and do another path unless there was an alternate exit or a hidden treasure. Both pathways lead to the end and have the same amount of gold
helpfulPercent: so unless there's a treasure there's not much point to making the choice other than
votesHelpful: again
votesTotal: deciding how much of a challenge you want.\n\nVisuals are very aesthetically pleasing and the design for the menus
commentsCount: and world map are nice and consistent. Some of the character designs were a little -too- weird for my taste but for the most part they are fun and interesting. Sound is great; Charles Martinet does some great voiceover work and the music - as to be expected - is well-suited to the gameplay and easy on the ears.\n\nI highly recommend this game. It's a fun platformer with a neat twist that will easily fill some spare time."

reviewText: This is easily in my top list of games, and my personal favourite of the Bit-Trip series. This game has a lot of charm, beggining right when you start up the game, from the announcer/narrator to the small doses of humour that are apparent thoughout the game. I also loved the art style which was a nice break from the rest of the Bit-Trip series. There are lots of unlockables, rewards, achievements, secrets, and levels to beat on easy, medium, and hard mode. In summary, there is lots to do and see, tons of charm, and overall it is a very entertaining game for casual and hardcore gamers alike.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Definitely one of the best Jump'n'Run games I ever played. Simple yet increasingly demanding gameplay paired with great music and sweet artstyle. I played through the game on normal difficulty and really enjoyed it. Completionists will be having a good (and probably hard) time to collect all gold nuggets, treasures and keys to unlock all levels, characters and costumes. Levels are always fair and managable, controls are also very responsive (I used my DualShock 3 hooked up via USB to my PC). Only thing you might consider is your display; the game is extremly fast paced so I recommend a good 120/144hz display to favor your eyes and minimize input lag for the best expierence.

tl;dr:
If you're looking for a great, classic Jump'n'Run expierence this is just the game for you. Highly recommended, would take it over the lastet Mario game any time.

reviewText: So I played the first Bit Trip Runner and while it was a fun game, I gave up on it since the difficulty randomly spiked up and I got stuck on one of the levels. This game fixed that. It's also possibly one of my more favorite releases last year amongst the hundreds of shooters, sandbox games, and strategy games both being released mainstream and indie alike. I'm a big fan of music video games, and that hasn't changed on the Bit Trip series. It's a simply game that's easy to pick up compared to the first, but there are still parts that will kick your ♥♥♥ like the bosses.

reviewText:
Sublime level design, wonderful music, and addresses every single issue from Runner 1. Also has one of the most... unique... art styles and senses of humor that I've seen in a long time. It’s creepy in a surprisingly hilarious way, and it’s certainly something new.

Okay, I’ll give. This is a ten-out-of-ten game. My one complaint was the unreliable and slightly luck-based dancing mechanic for high scores, but I managed to get to Rank 9 on the global leaderboard without trying very hard, so I can’t complain too much. Besides, you can enjoy this game just fine without even caring about score.

This is the best fixed-speed runner game on the market right now, and future runner games will have tall challenge if they want to top it.

This review brought to you in part by Shorty's Milk Brine: It could be worse."
"

reviewText:
Wow... That is all I can say when it comes to BIT.TRIP Runner2. I originally obtained this game from the recent humble bundle (which I regularly support) and was interested in its included soundtrack. Well, I decided to try it out and a few seconds later I started to feel this feeling that I haven't felt in a very long time... it was fun. This game is so simplistic in its design but executed so well. From the smiling trees in the backgrounds to the silly floating enemies watching  you as you hop on by, this is game truly shows character.

When a game developer puts time, love, and care into a game you can feel it, you can feel everything that the designers and artists felt. This is why I love this game and strongly recommend you purchase this game. You will spend hours jumping along with the music, and feeling that child like wonder we all crave and hold near and dear.

reviewText:
BTR2 does an excellent job of improving over its predecessor by distilling down the fun parts of the original and rebuilding itself around those concepts. Functionally it serves as a kind of pure-reflex rhythm game, with musical themes which bear repeating and creative use of an xbox-style controller. The visual upgrade to faux three-dimensionality does not accompany floaty or imprecise controls as is so often the case – in fact, the sequel has even tighter controls than the first, and every obstacle is clearly delineated without interrupting the overall graphical style.

Playing BTR2 can be a soothing, cathartic experience, but with variable difficulty levels and lots of hidden secrets there are plenty of challenges floating beneath the surface. This game is perfect for gamers of any age and ability, so long as they can enjoy Katamari-style quirkiness and the sense of achievement that comes with well-honed reflexes.

reviewText: The best bit.trip game in the series by far. Everything has gotten better, some examples are the soundtrack, achievements, and unlockables. The graphics have pushed away from an 8-bit style to a 3D cartoonish style. Normally I would shun a graphical change as huge as this in a video game series but the new look gives the game a unique advantage over the others. A relaxing rhythm game for newcomers and a challenging game for completionists. No matter how you play, you will love bit.trip.runner 2.

reviewText:
Even since I first saw the trailer of BIT.TRIP RUNNER, I was pretty much a fan of the genre, series and developer. When I first heard of Runner2 being released, I knew that I would get it, preferably as a pre-order. And get it I did!

At first I wasn't sure of the drastic change of the graphics style with the 'added dimension', but after pretty much the first map, I was sold.

The controls are responsive and easy to get a hold of. The gameplay is addictive, if a little repetitive. The content is solid, with 100 normal levels + a few retro ones, a bunch of different playable characters, mutliple difficulties, and collectibles!

The checkpoint, and having it optional, is a very good feature in Runner2. It lets the newer players feel less cheated when bonked near the end of a level and gives experienced players the option for more of a challenge along with a large point bonus.

I highly recommend this game, especially to fans of the original game.
Happy running!
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Very fun side scrolling platformer with a new and improved graphic style. It's a big improvement compared to the first game in terms of graphics, music, fluidity of platforming and more balanced difficulity.

The game generally gets harder as you play, which helps you get used to the new mechanics a lot easier. There is also incentive to replay levels to get keys, chests, and retro levels that you may have missed. There are also multiple unlockable characters that you can get, which also have their own multitude of costumes.

For a $15 game, this game is more than worth it.

reviewText:
아마도 내가 스팀에 입문하게 되면서 처음으로 전편과 DLC 및 본편의 게임을 정가를 주고 사게 만든 첫번째 인디 게임이었다.
구매 당시에는 스팀게임이 10개도 채 되지 않았을때였는데, 그때 당시에는 스마트폰의 흔하디 흔한 런너 게임들 같겠거니..하는 단순한 생각으로 현질 한번 한다는 마음으로 아무생각 없이 덜컥 구매를 해버렸다..  또한 다른 평들을 보자면, 쿠*런등과 같은 스마트폰에 널리고 널린 런너 게임과 비슷하다는 평들이 눈에 띄어 구매를 해버렸다( 당시에는 런너게임을 즐기고 있던 터였다).
하지만 이게임을 1시간 정도 즐기고 난 뒤의 나는 감히 쿠*런 따위와의 비교를 거부하게 되었다.
이제는 번들로많이 풀려서 내 친구님들 중에도 절반이상의 분들이 보유하고 계신데 인게임에서 랭킹을 보자면 5~6분 만이 랭크가 있을뿐이라 아쉬운 마음이 든다.
역시나 많은 분들이 흔한 런너 게임으로 취급하고 5~6판만 해본뒤에 봉인 된 게임으로 전락해버린것일지도 모른다.. ...
나역시 처음에는 그런마음으로 가볍게 시작했지만, 이게임의 진가는 1스테이지를 완료한 뒤부터 나온다. 아니, 1스테이지중 절반 이상만 클리어 한다면 장담컨데 감히 쿠*런 따위의 게임과 비교는 하지 않을것이다.
게임의 룰은 간다하다, 달리며 피하고 먹고, 막고, 찾기. 그리고 욕심난다면 더 높은 스코어를 향해 춤추기 ㅎ ㅎ
복잡한 길을 찾고 장비를 갖추고 스테이터스를 맞추고 선택을 하고 성장시키며 스토리를 이어가는 등의 복잡한룰따위는 찾아볼 수가 없다 정말 단순한 룰이지만 그렇기에 또한 매우 어려운 게임이기도 하다 (  머리로는 명령을 하지만 손가락이 따라주지 않는...)
이 게임의 장점은 너무나 많다.
수려한 그레픽으로 하는 내내 눈이 즐거우며, 게임이름 앞에 비트가 들어가기에 알겠지만, 흡사 리듬게임과 비슷할 만큼 게임속의 배경음은 귀에 착착 감기며 음악에 맞추어 액션을 행할수 하면서 고개를 흔들며 하는 자신을 볼수 있을것이다.
전편에 비해 체크포인트(중간지점)가 생겨서 전작에서 좌절하신 분들에게는 정말 즐겁게 즐길수 있는 게임이다.
또한 케릭터 언락이라던지 숨은 길을 찾는 재미라던지 보너스 스테이지를 하는 즐거움이 모자라지도 많지도 않아서 지루하지 않고 즐길수 있으며, 하나의 챕터를 한번만으로 끝내는것이 아니라 숨겨진 길을 찾은 뒤로는 곳곳에 기존에는 먹을 수 없거나 갈 수 없던 길을 진행하므로서 의외로 플레이타임을 늘려 장시간 즐길수 있다.
아기자기한 그레픽과 음악 , 귀여운 케릭터와 수집요소, 친구들과의 랭크등으로 이게임은 이미 흔한 런너 게임과는 차별이 되며 액션역시 너무 많아 하드모드를 하게 된다면 좌절하시는분들 여럿 생길 것이다.
그렇다고 단점이 없는 것은 아니다. 총 5개의 챕터로 이뤄져 있을 만큼 볼륨은 매우 적다.. 파고들기 식이 아닌 정주행 한번씩만 한다면 2~3시간이면 끝낼수도 있을만큼 볼륨은 적으며, 비트 라는 이름만큼의 중독성 있는 배경음악이 있지만, 그 음악 역시 비슷한 음악의 반복이므로 장시간 즐기게 된다면, 귀에서 16비트의 음이 난청처럼 들리게 될수도...ㅎ ㅎ ( 한마디로 음악은 좋지만 그 음악이 너무 단조롭고 그곡이 그곡같아서 아쉽다. ) /
또한 난이도 부족이랄까..나는.가장어려운 모드로 첫 플레이를 해봤지만 조금만 적응하게 되면 보통모드나 이지 모드의 경우에는 지루하기 짝이 없을만큼 너무 쉬워 져버린다.. 조금더 어려운 모드가 있었다면 하는 아쉬움도 있다. ( 그렇다고 내 실력이 탑이니 내가 엄청 잘하니 하는건 아니다....베리하드 1시간만 만져 보면 전체를 플레이하는데 전혀 지장이 없을정도이고.. 이게 적응되면 그 나머지 모드들은.....너무 쉽다..도전과제 하는데 지루할만큼..)
게임을 즐긴지는 오래되었는데, 이제와서 이렇게 장문의 글을 쓰는 이유는 친구에게 비트런너2를 선물하면서 같이 즐거움을 느끼고자 했건만.. 친구의 평은 쿠*런이나 윈*런너와 다른게 뭐냐 라는 어처구니 없는 평이 돌아와 확인해보니 플레이 타임 0.2시간... 요따위로 평가를 하기에 너무 아쉬운 나머지 이렇게 평을 적고 있다. ..
부디 이게임을 소지하고 ㄱㅖ신분들은 조금이라도 더 플레이 해보시기 바랍니다 ~ 엄청난 중독성으로 여타의 런너게임과는 결코 다른 재미를 체험하실수 있으실겁니다
게임 평점은 10점 만점중 9점이다.

This game's waaaay better than the first one, which was jsut horrible. The stage's are better and more fun, they have checkpoints you can take if you want to and it has a nice high score system where you see how your friends have done on the stages. The graphics are really pretty and I enjoyed them a lot. The music's decent.
The game's very simple because the characters run at a preset speed so you just need to avoid obstacles. For me that caused some focusing problems since I'm used to focusing on the character but here you need to focus on the stage. But it's no problem since it's probably because I'm autistic.
It took me 10 hours to complete on the normal difficulty but there's a lot of things to do if you want to 100% it. A lot of collectibles and extra stages and stuff like that.
I'll give it a 7/10, worth your money but it's very simple and thus gets a bit boring at times, unlike other platformers where you're in charge of the characters movement.

reviewText:
Shortly this is pretty much the best there is to runner games. Run and collect gold and try to make it to the end. Dont mess your rhytm or you will need to start again. Rinse and repeat - just throw in every now and then some retro bonus stages and optional paths to places where you can pick up new characters or costumes.

It can be just as punishing as you want - or quite easy if you set it up that way. Game completion is quite possible with just a mediocre skill set. Just dont expect to perfect this game anytime soon - good skills and resistance to rage quits is required for some achievements.

If you are contemplating on which one to grab first, this sequel or the first one i'd say make your selection according to how much punishment you like. The first one was pure skill and rhytm and it was not an easy game in any way in the later stages. This one has more variety and is more relaxed and easier on the eyes as it doesnt rely so much on the retro theme.

Very much worth it even today - especially at discount price.

reviewText:
BIT.TRIP Presents... Runner2: Future Legend of Rhythm Alien is an amazing game. IT is a straight upgrade from the original game, and it addresses most of the first game's faults, mainly difficulty. In the first game, if you got hit in a level, you would go all the way back to the start. In Runner 2, there are now checkpoints that save your progress after reaching the halfway point in the level. And this is where the game really shines. If you dont want to use checkpoints, or want that original Bit Trip feeling, you can jump over checkpoints and skip them, which even awards you bonus points for doing so. And if you find the game too easy, you can change the difficulty.

In terms of looks, Runner 2 is pleasing to look at. The graphics are pretty good, and the characters, backgrounds, environments, and objects are all very detailed, and they even interact with you ( enemy eyes will follow you as you jump
over them). They are a little jagged here and there, but they are very easy to forget about.

Gameplay is very solid, and Runner 2 's gameplay is very similar to the first, with differences here and there, such as loop de loops. The game is a little hard to play on keyboard, just due to the way the keys are laid out and you cant change what key does what, but it is managable when you get used to it. The game takes plae where th first left off, and there are five worlds with a huge amount of levels. Each world has a sort of base music, but each individual level has a different remix of the song. Just like in the first, whatever you do in the level adds to the song playing( gold pieces are spaced so when you collect each one, it makes a tune that goes with the song) The game is easy to pick up, since you start out with just jumping, before the game introduces you to sliding, blocking, kicking, and many other features. It gets difficult as you go on, but if its too hard you can just turn down the difficulty. The game also has a lrge amount of replayability, some levels are locked until you have a certain amount of gold, or some lvels are locked until you beat the key vault.

All in all, a very fun platformer. If you enjoyed the first, then youll love the second.

reviewText:
A game with multiple personality disorder. Runner games are typically reserved for casual game players and the overall colorful lightheartedness supports this. On the other hand the game seems to target old-school platformers with it's unerring demands and retro sections. It also seems to target that weird audience that thought Rayman's Raving Rabbids was the FUNNIEST THING with the awkward backgrounds, adult innuendos, and a sassy dancing hamburger person.

As far as the gameplay goes it's serviceable for a runner, it basically boils down to a string of quick time events, but the levels are mostly ho-hum. The problem is there are a ton of levels with little variety and many sections get terribly repetitive. There are some levels, as well as boss battles, where you can see how everything could come together if really implemented well. Unfortunately the good ideas are watered down among so many levels, I would rather see half as many levels but more tightly defined and better designed.

A large part of the game is the challenge of collecting all of the gold pieces within a level. It's an interesting diversion but with the aforementioned staleness of the levels I really stopped caring about 100% completion. All the gold is used for is unlocks of further levels (didn't I say there were too many already?) Add in that the developers have added other ways to get you replay levels (hidden keys, missing the target at the end, achievements that reward you for completing a level on all 3 difficulties!?) and the repetition goes through the roof. If there were fewer well designed levels I would care more about my score, practicing to get it -just right-, but the motivation just isn't there to do it again and again 100 times over. Even the leaderboard isn't much of a motivator as many scores seem to have been gained through exploitation and you would never get close by playing the game as intended.

With the constant repetition of levels the soundtrack gets old FAST. I can only platform to soothing jazz with timed bleeps for so long. Each world has essentially one song with slight variants as you play, I found the fire world to be the most engaging but the rest to be forgettable or slightly irritating. Alas with a game so focused on the tie-in with the music I would have hoped for more variety and higher quality.

There are other nit-picks here and there (inescapable intro, you can't remap buttons, it often errors when looking for leaderboards) but at the end of the day the biggest issue I have is with flow. With rhythm games it's all about getting in the zone
date: letting the music take you as you enjoy a grand musical adventure. Games like Beat Hazard, Rock Band, or Rez have this in spades; you are moving on instinct becoming one with the music. Sadly this game rarely offered those moments often jarring me out if I started to get into it. Whether it was from the camera zooming in or out at odd times, the overly busy backgrounds creating unnecessary distractions, or the one hit you die" mechanic taking me back to the start of the level due to questionable collision boxes
recommended: the game just wouldn't *let me enjoy it*.\n\nI really wanted to love this game but I've got to give it 1.5 out of 5 stars. There is a brilliant little soul hiding away somewhere in here but it is covered up by fluff and questionable design choices."

reviewText:
BIT.TRIP Runner 2 is a rhythm/platformer where you run along a path, collect gold, and avoid/defeat tons of obstacles along the way.

Much like the first BIT.TRIP Runner, I just couldn't enjoy this game despite my best efforts. The art is beautiful, and it's nice to see that Gaijin can make a beautiful, non-retro game. The music is wonderful as always. The gameplay, though... I normally really love music games of all sorts, but the gameplay is incredibly frustrating. The levels still go on way too long, and they're pretty hard, even near the beginning, which means that you will end up re-doing the same parts of the same levels over and over. I don't think the first Runner has a checkpoint system, and that is definitely a welcomed addition to Runner 2, but it's not enough. This game is certainly challenging, but for me, it wasn't a fun challenge at all.

The keyboard controls are baffling. You can use the arrow keys and space bar, which I highly recommend over what they tell you the controls are.

The BIT.TRIP series is a cool experiment in rhythm games, but Runner, for me, was a failed experiment and I don't know why that's the game that got a sequel. If you liked Runner, you'll love Runner 2, but I can't endorse this game for anyone else.

reviewText: A lot better than the original! Had a better difficulty curve so you weren't guaranteed PERFECTs for the first 15 levels. Checkpoints were kinder than the first game where you had to play the entire bloody level every time you even slightly cocked up but the checkpoints are still few and far between which is very annoying... Graphics made it a lot nicer and feel more alive. The cutscenes were irritating and the game would be better off without them but that doesn't make too much difference. The controls were very dodgy, and RETRO levels hurt your eyes like hell, and you couldn't see where gold was because of it being disguised with the background. Despite being better than the first one, that still doesn't make it good.

reviewText:
This game is a lot of fun when the game is on. You're running along the stage, collecting clumbs of gold and other things to improve your score. I like the soundtrack a lot, and it is often syncronised for the moment you pick up gold. It is a nice touch. It also offers secret Retro levels and unlockable characters.

However, even though the gameplay is a lot of fun, it has two very frustrating things that destroy the fun for me. It is a terrible PC game. I want to be able to configurate my own keyboard controls the way it works best for me, and not be forced to use a specific way of playing. It offers three different way to control with keyboard, but they are all clumsy to play with. I want to be able to spread my buttons, and this game does not allow me to do that. But I am sure if you got a controller, you will have a much better time.

Even though you collect all the clumbs of gold and other collectibles on a level, you are not getting a perfect score unless you do a totally out of place minigame at the end of the level. Your character jumps into a cannon, a big target shows up, and you need to time it right and shoot yourself into the centrum of the target to receive the perfect score. If you miss, you are not getting a perfect score even though you collected everything, and you have to redo the entire level again to get to the mini game, and hopefully do better. I feel good about doing well on the level and have collected everything, but the mini game at the end is like a smack in your face. It is very demotivating to continue playing when it is like that.

Allow me to configurate my keyboard controls like any other average, PC game allows you to, and get rid of the out of place mini game at the end of every freaking level so I can get the perfect score I am supposed to get when I collect everything. When the game has been fixed, I will recommend it a lot. It really is a lot of fun.

reviewText:
An improvement upon the already terrific original game in basically every way. Gaijin ditched the retro pixel-art look that had graced all their previous games in favor of improved, more modern visuals. While the old style definitely had some charm to it, the change is a very welcome one. The various backdrops are just beautiful. I've seen some people mention that the new art style can be too distracting, but so far it hasn't affected me negatively at all. The chiptune soundtrack is as catchy as ever and the game controls just perfectly; very responsive and accurate which makes getting into a good groove such a joy. I also like how Runner2 keeps the same basic rhythm-based gameplay from the original in tact while adding things like branching paths, cutscenes reminiscent of an old 50s serial, and a bunch of collectables to entice you to replay levels. It really does feel more like a full-featured game than the original.

There's also the addition of a checkpoint system and different difficulties to make the game more accessible to the novice/casual crowd. As someone who enjoyed the unrelenting nature of the original, I'm alright with this. Veterans can skip checkpoints entirely in favor of bonus points and bump the difficulty up from the onset to get the best challenge. It's a smart move by the developers and a win-win for everyone.

If you liked the original Bit.trip Runner, Runner2 is more of the same and then some. It's exactly what you'd want out of a sequel: It keeps the established gameplay in place while making some necessary and welcome improvements along the way. Even if you didn't like the original because of its difficulty, the more accessible nature could put Runner2 right up your alley. Absolutely recommended.

reviewText: This sequel is definitely a more well rounded and welcoming game for everyone. Runner 2 is not plagued by the uneven and harsh splike in difficulty that upset so many in the first iteration. It has much more content than the original, it has three different difficulty levels to accomidate a player's skill set, and it also now has checkpoints. For those who relished the challenge of the first game...don't worry, the hard difficulty setting will give you everything you ask for, and you have the option to skip checkpoints for bonus points. The graphical style of this game is much different and does look quite a lot better...however I think I still have a preference for the way the first game looked. The game is also narrated by Charles Martinet who is best known for doing the voicework for Mario. I imagine this will be a plus for some and an annoyance to others. As with the first game, in my opinioin the music is also very good in Runner 2 and helps to keep pushing the player through those difficult spots. The biggest issue I have with the game is how some of the achievements are tied in with the bullseye minigame event that takes place at the end of each level (assuming you have collected all the gold pieces). I think the achievements should have been related to whether you chose to skip the optional checkpoint or not, and the minigame at the end should only have served as a mechanism to increase the player's score. At the end of the day it is a very good game that will give you about five to six hours on just a normal playthrough and probably twenty plus hours if you try to 100 percent the game.

reviewText: This game is a huge improvement over the first one in my honest opinion. As soon as you jump into the first level you'll see the amount of effort and love that has been put into Runner 2 visuals and graphics. Despite the fact that they are gorgeous I have one complaint, sometimes in certain levels, specially in the last world, the background really got in the way of my gameplay, I couldn't destinguish what was the background and what was the level itself, this might be just me but be advised. Other than that Runner 2 is much more simple and the difficulty curve is not as huge as in the first game, I never got into the first Runner game because it was too hardcore and there were no checkpoints in the level. The soundtrack is of course a huge part in this game, it helps you keeping up on the rhythm while jumping etc. Overall I'd say that this is amongst the best games that I've played this year and I recommend it to pretty much anyone who is looking for a fun game.

reviewText:
This game.... Ha. It's a sequel to one of the most brilliant series to ever be made. RIT.TRIP is WIDELY unrecognized as the genius it is. It's a music game, of sorts, but it's also a rail shooter, Pong, reverse Pong, and in this case, an autorun platformer.

If you don't buy this game, you're missing out. If you buy it, play it, and don't like it, then you don't deserve breath in your body, because all you're doing with it is feeding a dead mass you call a brain, but all it's really doing is firing off basic impulses to keep you alive. For no reason.

Retro gamers will find solace in the voice of the announcer. I'll leave it at that, those that know the name will KNOW the name.

Also, it's important to note that if you suck at this game, it's entirely your fault. You can blame the controller, maybe lag, anything. Find something, and blame it. You'll know deep down in the back of your mind it's because you ♥♥♥♥ed up. It was YOUR fault you fell in that hole. It's YOUR fault you ran into those spikes.

And it will eat at you. You'll get ♥♥♥♥♥♥, walk away, smash your controller/PC/monitor, but...

You'll be back.

You'll always come back.

reviewText:
This    Game    Is     Hard

But ... don't let that stop you from trying it... I love it.

No game since Super Meat Boy has made me shake the controller in anger like this one. I still haven't quite finished it but I'm close. Each level has 1 continue spot in it half way through. If you get hit you are either sent back to the beginning or the half way point depending on where you bite it. And when you've dodged about 100 things and get sent back... argh!

Up side:
1. Colorful graphics. The worlds really look wonderful.
2. The music. I love the main song of the game. Gets me fired up to play it everytime.

Down side:
1. Maddeningly hard on some levels. But... that's what you are paying for. If the game just let you keep playing through without reseting you to a start point you'd miss the point of the game: fine tuned reflexes and course memorization
2. The backgrounds can really be distracting causing you to hit enemies/obstacles.

Completing levels in this game gives you a huge sense of accomplishment. You earn every inch of this game and every inch is awesome.

reviewText:
This is a pretty fantastic game. Awesome platforming and awesome music. It gets you in to a sort of trance where you almost don't realize what you're doing, you just instinctively press the buttons.

Like a round of ping pong where both opponents have their A-game and it seems like the volley never stops and you're left wondering who's gonna screw first, you or your opponent. Only your opponent is each well crafted level. And you're not ping ponging, you're running.

While some people might complain about the lack of retro graphics the first game, I found these graphics to be a lot easier on the eyes. Nice pastel colors with the occasional bright colors make it lots of fun to watch in motion.

So yes, I recommend this game.

reviewText:
This game rocks. It is a fast paced runner game where the music really immerses you deeper in their universe. It is easy to pick up and play - and the game does a great job of introducing new moves and mechanics the deeper you get in the game. Bit Trip trains you well slowly and by the end of the game you feel like a pro!

Music! Every world and level has unique music - but what really stands out is every time you collect something - it feels like it is to the beat. The more you collect - the better the music and you end up having even more fun!

Frustration factor is ZERO, but that does not mean it isn't challenging. There are multiple difficulty levels so you can still feel challenged - but not once did I want to throw a controller because of wonky gameplay design or controls. It is a smooth experience from start to finish.

Length! There is 5 unique worlds with about 15-20 levels per world. You can unlock new characters and go into a few secret 8bit worlds. You will not be disappointed by the length of the game - and at no point does it begin to feel overly repetitive.

I highly recommend this game if you are looking for phenomenal music and stunning art. It is a running game with great controls. Jokes are peppered throughout the story and high production value shines in Gaijin Game's Bit.Trip Runner 2!
